abstract_summ: We describe a patient in Wuhan, China, with severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 infection who had progressive pulmonary lesions and rhabdomyolysis with manifestations of lower limb pain and fatigue.Rapid clinical recognition of rhabdomyolysis symptoms in patients with severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 infection can be lifesaving.The limited clinical data about the virus's behavior to date, especially extrapulmonary symptoms, suggest that we should be aware of the possibility of initial cerebrovascular manifestations of COVID-19.• MG treatment in the context of COVID-19 should be tailored to the patient.A 10-year-old male with prolonged fever, rash, and conjunctivitis presented to the emergency department with concern for Kawasaki disease, found to have myocarditis and PCR positive for SARS-CoV-2.• Concomitant COVID-19 and MG has a variable response to treatment.• Recent reports of Guillain-Barré Syndrome associated with COVID-19 have described both the axonal and demyelinating subtypes.
title_summ: COVID-19 and Kawasaki syndrome: should we really be surprised?COVID-19 and intracerebral haemorrhage: causative or coincidental?COVID-19 and Generalized Myasthenia Gravis Exacerbation: A Case ReportDoes COVID-19 cause axonal GBS?Rhabdomyolysis as Potential Late Complication Associated with COVID-19Kawasaki Disease Features and Myocarditis in a Patient with COVID-19Coagulopathy and Antiphospholipid Antibodies in Patients with Covid-19Thrombocytopenia as an initial manifestation of Covid-19; Case Series and Literature review.
